I can't speak to liposuction, but that is perfectly ignorant nonsense about Lasik. It is a safe procedure, that has been done hundreds of thousands of times, and with a very high rate of success and relatively few complications.

Clear vision is a pretty darned important thing in life. It sounds like you've never had to wear glasses -- they fog up, get in the way of you doing outdoor sports, frost up in cold weather, BREAK, cost about $400 a pair for good quality progressive bifocals, aren't paid for by most health insurance (but need replacing every year or two), are uncomfortable (hot and sweaty), cause breakouts, and are just generally uncomfortable.

Some people like me never got a satisfactory correction from "reading glasses". I can see distance just fine; indeed I sacrificed some distance vision to get greatly improved reading vision (I'm farsighted and have presbyopia). However, the greatest improvement I've seen is in near sighted folks, who can go from 20/200 vision to better than 20/20 vision in a few minutes.

It's not for everyone, but for those who really can benefit, it's a miracle. I suppose you also oppose intraoccular lenses for patients with cataracts -- after all, they can "just wear inch thick glasses".

Actually, liposuction causes people to be more prone to gaining fat regardless. People have had lipo done on those 'stubborn small areas' (marketing words used by purveyors of lipo) only  to see their figures destroyed by weight gain, even if their weight was stable for years (lipo does not cause you to lose weight).

I think the premise of the study and the article is that those who underwent liposuction continued to eat the same amount and kinds of food as they ate before the surgery. It is only logical that the same eating pattern that got them fat in the first place would continue making them fat.

Therefore, the point of the article is: if you want to keep off the fat that liposuction took out, you better exercise if you are going to stick with your old eating habits. Or you could simply change your eating habits after liposuction if you don't want to exercise. Or you could do both and lose even more fat after liposuction.

Although this is a no-brainer for almost all of us (diet and exercise to lose fat), the clincher for such a proposition is the finding mentioned in the article that after liposuction, any fat gained will be deposited as visceral fat (that cannot be physically removed), not subcutaneous fat (that can be removed by further liposuction).

In short, start exercising and/or dieting after liposuction because any fat you gain (from your unhealthy eating habits) from that point onwards will turn to visceral fat, which could compromise your life span.

I'm glad more exercise is recommended. For those who elect to have liposuction, they may feel that exercise is no longer necessary, but it is evident that exercise should continue. I do worry about the long term health of those that rely on lipo to keep a trim figure.

Liposuction is *not* painful at all. The painkillers are mild, and many people need to only take them for a few days. If you haven't had it done, you shouldn't be making bold statements about pain levels.

I've had it done. It was far less painful than my nose job, tummy tuck, or breast lift and augmentation.

You are correct in stating that lipo is for sculpting diet and exercise-resistant fat pockets.

I think one thing overlooked -- liposuction is VERY painful. That fat tissue is real human tissue, with pain and nerve endings and a blood supply.

After surgery, you have to wear a miserable girdle-like contraption, and you are in agony -- often on heavy pain killers.

I can't imagine anyone even being able TO exercise effectively after liposuction -- not for several months. And certainly not until they could take off the "girdle" device.

I want to emphasize that no reputable surgeon would do liposuction on an obese patient. Liposuction is the sculpting of rather small parts of the body, that resist all efforts to diet or exercise ANYWAYS.

You can't just "vacuum out" 100 lbs of fat. If you tried to, the patient would look all lump and deformed.

Most lipo only removed small amounts of fat -- a few pounds, sometimes just ounces.

Most results I have seen are pretty good for what they are. And most reputable surgeons will not promise to turn you into a supermodel, just a more attractively shapely version of who you already are.

David Burnett, you speak with humility and yet eloquence of the photographer's art--and if you are the same David Burnett I am thinking of, then it is no surprise. Are you the photographer whose work I came upon nearly 30 years ago as a picture researcher for The Vietnam Experience, an illustrated book series on the war? I found your work in Newsweek or Time or one of the other magazines of the time, contacted you, and subsequently published some of your pictures in our books. I believe we met when you visited our offices at Boston Publishing Company. I have never lost my appreciation of beautiful, compelling, insightful imagery... It must be in my DNA. My 21-year-old daughter is now studying photography in college, planning her senior thesis around a photo project, and soaking up everything she can about its history.

In the small-world department, commenting below, John G. Morris mentions another colleague from my Vietnam Experience days--Kate Lewin--who worked as our Paris-based picture researcher. A highlight of that job, for me, was visiting the major photo archives such as Magnum, Black Star, Life Picture Service, UPI/Bettmann, etc., to pore over the files of some amazing and iconic images and actually hold them in my hands. I will never forget the day the great Alfred Eisenstadt (he, of the Sailor-kissing-the-nurse-in-Times-Square-on-VJ-Day fame) appeared in the offices of LPS as I watched, awestruck. He was pint-sized, charming and full of life.

One of the great things about all these wonderful pictures is that when they were working, when they were SHOOTING the images on those old antiquarian cameras with sheet film and plates.. the photographers  didn't really KNOW, or probably even THINK that we would be so rapturous over them.  Maybe they saw their mission as an important one, to raise spirits at a time they needed raising , with photography, but I for one am pleased that there is very little self congratulatory attitude in the work. It was good photographers, guided by a visionary editor, who just went out into the world, reacted to it and shot some really great photographs.  Who could ask for more?
